posts:
<row Id="1" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-07-20T19:09:27.200" ViewCount="8695" Score="155" CommentCount="0" OwnerUserId="10" Title="What Does it Really Mean to Have Different Kinds of Infinities?" Body="
Can someone explain to me how there can be different kinds of infinities?
I was reading "The man who loved only numbers" by Paul Hoffman and came across the concept of countable and uncountable infinities, but they're only words to me.
Any help would be appreciated. " AnswerCount="9" AcceptedAnswerId="9" Tags=""/> <row Id="3" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-07-20T19:12:14.353" ViewCount="70334" Score="120" CommentCount="3" OwnerUserId="29" Title="List of interesting math podcasts?" Body="
mathfactor is one I listen to. Does anyone else have a recommendation? " AnswerCount="20" Tags=""/> <row Id="4" PostTypeId="2" CreationDate="2010-07-20T19:14:10.603" Score="11" CommentCount="1" OwnerUserId="31" Body="
More or Less is a BBC Radio 4 programme about maths and statistics in the news, and there is a free podcast. It's presented by Tim Harford, the Undercover Economist from the Financial Times. " ParentId="3"/> <row Id="5" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-07-20T19:18:01.250" ViewCount="12722" Score="54" CommentCount="7" OwnerUserId="38" Title="How can you prove that the square root of two is irrational?" Body="
I have read a few proofs that \sqrt{2} is irrational.
I have never, however, been able to really grasp what they were talking about.
Is there a simplified proof that \sqrt{2} is irrational? " AnswerCount="14" AcceptedAnswerId="7" Tags=""/> <row Id="6" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-07-20T19:20:00.543" ViewCount="4979" Score="43" CommentCount="0" OwnerUserId="41" Title="What is your favorite online graphing tool?" Body="
I'm looking for a nice, quick online graphing tool. The ability to link to, or embed the output would be handy, too. " AnswerCount="8" AcceptedAnswerId="281" Tags=""/> <row Id="7" PostTypeId="2" CreationDate="2010-07-20T19:21:52.240" Score="80" CommentCount="10" OwnerUserId="45" Body="
You use a proof by contradiction. Basically, you suppose that \sqrt{2} can be written as p/q. Then you know that 2q^2 = p^2. However, both q^2 and p^2 have an even number of factors of two, so 2q^2 has an odd number of factors of 2, which means it can't be equal to p^2. " ParentId="5"/> <row Id="8" PostTypeId="1" CreationDate="2010-07-20T19:22:12.190" ViewCount="1842" Score="35" CommentCount="0" OwnerUserId="40" Title="How are we able to calculate specific numbers in the Fibonacci Sequence?" Body="
I was reading up on the Fibonacci Sequence, \text {{1,1,2,3,5,8,13,....}} when I've noticed some were able to calculate specific numbers. So far I've only figured out creating an array and counting to the value, which is incredibly simple, but I reckon I can't find any formula for calculating a Fibonacci number based on it's position.
Is there a way to do this? If so, how are we able to apply these formulas to arrays? " AnswerCount="7" AcceptedAnswerId="17" Tags=""/>
